description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.

description: Starting from 16 March 2020, vacations are announced in kindergardens, schools and universities of Uzbekistan for three weeks. A special commission to prevent the spread of coronavirus infection and ensure the sanitary and epidemiological situation in educational institutions, headed by the Prime Minister of Uzbekistan Abdulla Aripov, made such a decision on 15 March 2020. Children can receive knowledge during the holidays, the National Television and Radio Company of Uzbekistan will prepare and organize the broadcasting of video lessons in accordance with the curriculum. UPDATE: In the Republic of Uzbekistan, according to the decision of the Special Republican Commission made on April 21, 2020, the academic year in the system and institutions of the Ministry of Public Education will end remotely as part of the Online-maktab ("Online School") television project. Teachers and employees of the public education sector involved in the organization of distance learning will continue to work remotely (with the payment of their salaries).

description: In Uzbekistan, due to the increase in the incidence of coronavirus infection among students and teachers of secondary schools in Tashkent, from March 16, 2021, all schools in Mirzo-Ulugbek, Chilanzar and Yunusabad districts will be transferred to online learning for a one-time quarantine period (14 days). Non-governmental and private educational organizations operating in these areas are also recommended to transfer students to distance learning from March 16 for a one-time quarantine period (14 days). In other districts of the capital, training will continue until spring break as usual (March 20 to 29, 2021), with full compliance with quarantine requirements.

In other districts of the capital, training will continue until spring break as usual (March 20 to 29, 2021), with full compliance with quarantine requirements.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Uzbekistan, from April 27 to May 10, a 14-day quarantine is being introduced in all schools and preschool educational organizations of Samarkand. The decision to transfer to online education was made in connection with a sharp increase in the incidence of coronavirus infection in schools and preschool educational institutions, a representative of the city administration explained. Educational institutions will return to the traditional form of education on May 10, including schools and kindergartens, which were closed for quarantine until April 27.

description: With technical support from UNICEF and WHO, Uzbekistan has formally submitted the National COVID-19 Vaccine Deployment Plan to the COVAX-facility. By officially submitting the plan, the Government of Uzbekistan is indicating that they are prepared to receive and deploy COVID-19 vaccines to target populations. UNICEF and WHO continue to provide technical support to the Government to ensure that Uzbekistan meets all requirements before receiving COVID-19 vaccines.

description: On 17 March, 2020, at a meeting of a special commission of the Cabinet of Ministers, it has been announced that the validity period of a visa of foreign citizens located in the Republic of Uzbekistan will be automatically extended until 10 April 2020. Also, citizens of countries with the right to enter the country without a visa for a certain period of time (in case of violation of the established period) will be allowed to leave the country as an exception by 10 April 2020. In the above cases no measures will be taken against them. According to this decision, the Uzbek Foreign Ministry asks the leaders of hotel complexes, taking into account the current situation, to accept foreign citizens into accommodation facilities without any problems.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On 17 March, 2020, at a meeting of a special commission of the Cabinet of Ministers, it has been announced that the validity period of a visa of foreign citizens located in the Republic of Uzbekistan will be automatically extended until 10 April 2020. Also, citizens of countries with the right to enter the country without a visa for a certain period of time (in case of violation of the established period) will be allowed to leave the country as an exception by 10 April 2020. In the above cases no measures will be taken against them. According to this decision, the Uzbek Foreign Ministry asks the leaders of hotel complexes, taking into account the current situation, to accept foreign citizens into accommodation facilities without any problems. UPDATE: The visa period for foreign citizens currently staying in the territory of the Republic of Uzbekistan has been automatically extended until 1 November 2020. This is stated in the decision of the Republican Special Commission on the preparation of a program of measures to prevent the penetration and spread of coronavirus in Uzbekistan on 30 July 2020.

target_geog_level: All countries

description: On September 21, Uzbekistani authorities have announced that the country's borders are to reopen from October 1, following a months-long closure due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. Cross-border traffic and international trains and flights are expected to resume over the course of the month. Countries have been classified under a traffic light system as 'green', 'yellow', or 'red', depending on the levels of COVID-19 infection in each country, with different regulations regarding entry depending on the color. Travelers arriving from 'green' countries, which include China, Thailand, Malaysia, South Korea, Georgia, Hungary, Finland, Latvia, Austria, and Japan, will be able to enter Uzbekistan without restrictions. Those arriving from 'yellow' countries, which consist of Azerbaijan, Belarus, the UAE, and the EU (except for the UK and Spain) may enter provided they have undergone a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test in the 72 hours prior to their arrival.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On September 21, 2020, Uzbekistani authorities have announced that the country's borders are to reopen from October 1, following a months-long closure due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. Cross-border traffic and international trains and flights are expected to resume over the course of the month. Countries have been classified under a traffic light system as 'green', 'yellow', or 'red', depending on the levels of COVID-19 infection in each country, with different regulations regarding entry depending on the color. Travelers arriving from 'green' countries, which include China, Thailand, Malaysia, South Korea, Georgia, Hungary, Finland, Latvia, Austria, and Japan, will be able to enter Uzbekistan without restrictions. Those arriving from 'yellow' countries, which consist of Azerbaijan, Belarus, the UAE, and the EU (except for the UK and Spain) may enter provided they have undergone a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test in the 72 hours prior to their arrival. All other countries have been classified as 'red', and arrivals must provide a negative PCR test and undergo a 14-day quarantine to be permitted entry.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Uzbekistan extends entry restrictions for numerous countries until March 1 over high COVID-19 activity; domestic restrictions in effect. Quarantine restrictions are exempt for those from Green locations; 14-day period for Yellow locations; 14-days for Uzbek nationals returning from Red locations. Authorities have designated countries Green, Yellow, or Red, depending on their assessment of the epidemiological threat in each. As of the most recent review, the designations are as follows: Arrivals from Green locations - including Japan, South Korea, China, and Israel - are permitted to enter without restriction. Travelers who have visited any Yellow location - including Azerbaijan and EU member states (except those listed above) - within the previous 10 days must self-isolate for 14 days on arrival. Nonresidents who have visited any Red location - all remaining countries - within the previous 10 days are prohibited from entry. Uzbek nationals returning from a Red country will be quarantined in a state facility for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Travelers who have visited any Yellow location - including Azerbaijan and EU member states (except those listed above) - within the previous 10 days must self-isolate for 14 days on arrival. description: Authorities of Uzbekistan have closed all land border crossings with Afghanistan except for the Termez-Avtoyul border checkpoint. Only freight transporters, citizens, and permanent residents of Uzbekistan and diplomats may enter Uzbekistan through the Termez-Avtoyul border checkpoint. Permitted travelers must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test no more than 72 hours old to border officials. Travelers will also be subject to a rapid antigen test at the border. Uzbek nationals who fail the test will be quarantined in a government facility, while foreign nationals who fail the test will be barred from entry. All persons permitted to enter the country must take a COVID-19 PCR within seven days. Additionally, Uzbekistan Airways (HY) has reduced flights with India.    While international travel is permitted, flight suspensions with several countries, including the UK, remain in place. Additionally, due to low demand, flights from several other destinations have been effectively suspended.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 26, 2020, in the Republic of Uzbekistan, President Shavkat Mirziyoyev chaired a videoconference on strengthening the fight against the spread of coronavirus infection. He announced that, in order to provide qualified medical assistance to citizens placed in quarantine, construction of a quarantine zone for 10 thousand beds is being completed in Urtachirchik district of Tashkent region. Two infectious diseases hospitals for 5000 beds are also being built in the region. The first unit for a thousand beds will be put into operation in the coming days. In addition, Surkhandarya, Namangan and Navoi regions have started equipping modular clinics for a thousand places each, as well as quarantine stations.

description: In the Republic of Uzbekistan, according to the reports on March 26, 2020, The Special Commission announced the construction of special hospitals. Three modern specialized medical institutions are being built in the city of Tashkent. The first is the buildings of the newly built Children's Infectious Diseases Hospital No. 3 (144 beds) and the Children's Cardiorheumatology Clinical Hospital No. 4 (158 beds) in Chilanzar district, their commissioning is planned for the coming months. Work is also underway to transform the new building of the Tashkent Dental Institute in Yashnabad district into a modern medical facility with 250 beds.  In addition, 55 hectares of land were allocated in the Yukorichirchik district of the Tashkent region for the construction of a quarantine facility. Another large institution will be built in the Zangiata district. These days, on the allocated 27 hectares of land, work is actively underway to build a hospital with 10,000 beds. The same buildings for quarantine and treatment of those infected with coronavirus infection are being built in Andijan, Navoi and Surkhandarya regions.

All international arrivals will need to undergo a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test for COVID-19; testing will take place at international airports, railway stations and land border checkpoints; those with positive test results will be quarantined in a government facility, likely for 14 days.

description: In Uzbekistan, since March 27, interregional traffic has been suspended for all types of vehicles, with the exception of freight traffic. This was announced by the Minister of Internal Affairs of Uzbekistan Pulat Babadzhanov.In order to prevent the spread of coronavirus, as well as to ensure sanitary and epidemiological safety of the population, from 10 a.m. on March 27 interregional traffic for all types of vehicles (cars, buses, air and rail transport) was stopped, the Interior Ministry said in a statement.The exception applies only to vehicles intended for freight traffic.We ask citizens not to go outside without special need, and also not to leave the zone of residence. The above measures are designed to prevent the spread of a dangerous virus and protect the health of every citizen of our country, the Interior Ministry emphasized.On March 27, the first death among patients with coronavirus was recorded in Uzbekistan, and the number of people infected with this virus reached 83 people.

description:
From 00:01 on March 24, 2020, all types of transport, including buses, cars, air and railway transport, will be closed from Tashkent. This decision was made on Monday by the Special Republican Commission for the fight against coronavirus, according to the telegram channel Koronavirus Info.
The restriction on entry and exit from the capital of Uzbekistan does not apply to cargo transportation. Only citizens permanently residing (registered) in Tashkent will be able to enter the city. UPDATE: The policy has been annulled because all inter-regional traffic for all types of vehicles (cars, buses, air and rail) was stopped from 10:00 a.m. of 27 March. description: By the decision of the Republican special commission to prepare a program of measures to prevent the entry and spread of coronavirus into the Republic of Uzbekistan, the following procedures are introduced: From 06:00 a.m. April 30:  Citizens are allowed to use their own vehicles (together with passengers) from 7:00 to 10:00 in the morning and from 17:00 to 20:00 in the evening (including bicycles and motor vehicles). The use of personal vehicles is allowed primarily for citizens traveling to work, to medical institutions and returning home, in order to purchase consumer goods, medicines and medical devices.  Citizens are allowed to walk in front of residential buildings in cities and districts and in courtyards, observing the social distance (distance of 2 meters) in medical masks. Children under 14 years old should only be accompanied by their parents on the street;  The heads of higher educational institutions and research institutes, as well as professors are allowed to restore laboratory and other activities to continue scientific work.  It is allowed to carry out interregional and intercity transportation for the delivery and sale of fruits and vegetables and melons grown by farmers and dehkans. It should be noted that while traveling in public places, markets and authorized retail outlets, as well as in motor vehicles, everyone is required to strictly observe the sanitary and hygienic rules established by a special commission.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since April 6, in Tashkent, Nukus, as well as regional centers, the selfisolation regime introduced on April 1 becomes mandatory. Such a decision at a meeting on April 4 was adopted by the Special Republican Commission to Combat Coronavirus.The input mode implies:There is a strict restriction on leaving the place of residence, except for visiting trade objects in the area of residence when absolutely necessary (for the purchase of products, medicines and medical devices) or medical facilities. The exception is visiting a place of work;When moving around the streets, as well as visiting trade objects and other places, maintaining a social distance of 2 meters is required;Citizens over 65 years of age and having chronic diseases are strictly forbidden to leave home without emergency.Citizens who violate these requirements may be held liable in accordance with the law.

description: According to the order of Special Comission of Uzbekistan on April 14, 2020, following all regional centers, in five major cities of Tashkent Region - Almalyk, Bekobod, Angren, Yangiyul and Chirchik - introduce self-isolation regime. Restrictions include: walking dogs should be done once a day and at a distance of no more than 100 meters from the house; citizens over 65 years of age are not allowed to leave their homes, an exception is made for trips to grocery stores and pharmacies located in the immediate vicinity of their homes; other residents should also leave their homes only for trips to grocery stores and pharmacies located in the immediate vicinity of their homes; when moving around the streets, as well as visiting trade objects and other places, it is necessary to maintain a social distance of 2 meters.

description: Authorities in Uzbekistan have extended the nationwide lockdown measures until August 1 in order to limit the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). The system of 'green', 'yellow', and 'red' zones will continue, with different measures in place depending on the amount of COVID-19 cases present in each zone. 'Green' and 'yellow' zones are to lift restrictions on schools on Monday, June 15. State kindergartens are to reopen on August 1. On June 15, Uzbek authorities eased transportation measures amid a decrease in the number of COVID-19 cases. The Ministry of Transport stated that certain international flights are to resume with restrictions based on the country of departure's epidemic situation. Citizens and those with permanent residency, as well as individuals associated with certain business and diplomatic organizations and their families, will be allowed to enter and leave the country at free will.    Furthermore, train service from Tashkent to various other cities throughout the country has resumed, with schedules based on the epidemiological situation in their respective regions.    The wearing of masks, the use of hand sanitizer, and the maintaining of social distancing are mandatory.

description: On January 29, 2020, The President of Uzbekistan signed a decree on the creation of a special republican commission to prepare a program of measures to prevent the importation and spread of a new type of coronavirus in Uzbekistan. The commission was headed by Prime Minister Abdulla Aripov. A special republican commission was created under the leadership of Abdulla Aripov. The commission’s tasks include continuous analysis and monitoring of the global, regional and country epidemiological conditions, forecasting the trends in the spread and possible worsening of the epidemiological situation of coronavirus in the country.

description: In Uzbekistan, on the basis of the Presidential Decree dated on March 19, 2020, the Republican Anti-Crisis Commission (hereinafter referred to as the “Anti-Crisis Commission“) was formed. The main task of the Anti-Crisis Commission is to resolve issues and ensure the work of economic sectors, social support of the population during the period of counteracting the spread of coronavirus infection. The territorial headquarters of the Anti-Crisis Commission are headed by the Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Karakalpakstan, khokims of regions, districts and cities respectively. The Prime Minister is also the head of the Anti-Crisis Commission.

description: In accordance with the instructions of President Shavkat Mirziyoyev, the Republican AntiCrisis Commission is working to ensure the stable operation of the leading sectors of the economy in the context of the coronavirus epidemic and prevent declining incomes.In particular, in the regions of the country where coronavirus infection has not been detected or the epidemiological situation has improved, the gradual easing of quarantine restrictions and the continuation of the activities of businesses operating in certain sectors of the economy.In order to combat the spread of coronavirus infection in the country, to ensure the sustainable operation of industrial, infrastructure, transport and logistics entities, the decision of the Republican Commission for Combating the Crisis was adopted.This resolution allows a number of sectors of the economy to operate in the event of an epidemic to ensure the sustainable operation of sectors of the economy, prevent the growth of unemployment among the population and ensure budget revenues.In particular, markets for construction materials, including businesses engaged in retail and wholesale trade in construction materials (area not less than 500 sq.m.);to network shops (stores) of large producers in the areas intended for the sale of their products (sanitary norm on the basis of the order of 1 buyer per 10 sq.m.).
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: In accordance with the instruction of the President of the country given on May 7, 2020, the Republican Special Commission divided administrative territories into “green”, “yellow” and “red” zones. In this case, registered cases of the disease, the presence of patients or recurring cases of the disease are taken into account. The “green” zone currently has no patients or all patients have fully recovered and are undergoing rehabilitation. The “yellow” zone includes regions where no one has been infected with coronavirus during the last 14 days, but there are people with this disease, the “red” zone includes regions where the coronavirus disease was diagnosed in the last 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: State Committee for Tourism Development announced the introduction of the automated system, E-Mehmon. This system aims to ensure the safety of health and property of local and foreign tourists, protecting their legitimate interests and providing guaranteed services. Now all persons who have used the services of accommodation facilities, including citizens of the Republic of Uzbekistan, foreign citizens and stateless persons, must be registered in hotels, medical institutions, sanatoriums, rest homes and other institutions on the basis of identity documents, by the administration of these institutions through entering into the automated information system E-Mehmon. Registration is carried out at the time of arrival of citizens (earlier - within 12 hours) and regardless of the period of their stay.

description: On March 20, 2020, thr Special Republican Commission of Uzbekistan organizes flights for the return of compatriots to their homeland. The Commission promptly developed a schedule of charter flights, providing for the arrival of airliners in Uzbekistan. The export of fellow citizens by charter flight from other countries will continue. Information on the departure schedule for the following days will be announced later. All citizens of Uzbekistan upon return will be placed in 14-day quarantine with strict observance of the relevant requirements and norms of the UN World Health Organization.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: The Government of Uzbekistan has ordered to place all those who have been in China, France, Germany, Iran, Italy, Japan, South Korea and Spain in a 14 day quarantine, reported on February 28, 2020. UPDATE: The original quarantine policy was been annulled because, on 23 March, 2020, the Government of Uzbekistan adopted a new resolution "On additional measures to prevent the spread of coronavirus infection" according to which there is a requirement to place all people arriving to the Republic of Uzbekistan under 14-day quarantine in specially designated medical institutions or bases adapted for organizing quarantine measures, or at home.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 1, 2020, the Ministry of Transport of Uzbekistan has officially notified the aviation authorities and companies of the Republic of Korea about the introduction of temporary restrictive measures in air communication between the two countries from 1 March 2020. description: On August 12, 2020, by the decision of the special commission, the list of  "red", "yellow" and "green" countries has been updated. The list of countries where the number of cases of coronavirus is decreasing includes the countries of the European Union (with the exception of Spain), as well as Azerbaijan (“yellow” ). If travelers have been in these countries for 10 days, they will be placed in a 14-day home quarantine upon arrival. According to the decision of the commission, the quarantine period can be reduced to 7 days if the citizen follows treatment and preventive measures under the supervision of doctors (with medication recommended by the Ministry of Health). In case of negative test results for coronavirus, after 7 days of quarantine, a citizen leaves the quarantine zone.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings

description: On August 12, 2020, by the decision of the special commission, the list of  "red", "yellow" and "green" countries has been updated.  The category of countries where the number of cases of coronavirus does not decrease includes all countries (“red” ), except China, Thailand, Malaysia, South Korea, Georgia, Hungary, Latvia, Japan, Azerbaijan, and the European Union (with the exception of Spain). Upon arrival, passengers will be placed in a 14-day quarantine. According to the decision of the commission, the quarantine period can be reduced to 7 days if the citizen follows treatment and preventive measures under the supervision of doctors (with medication recommended by the Ministry of Health). In case of negative test results for coronavirus, after 7 days of quarantine, a citizen leaves the quarantine zone.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On 23 March, 2020, the Government of Uzbekistan adopted a resolution "On additional measures to prevent the spread of coronavirus infection." According to the resolution, there is a requirement to place all people arriving to the Republic of Uzbekistan from other countries under 14-day quarantine in specially designated medical institutions or bases adapted for organizing quarantine measures, or at home. UPDATE: According to the news on September 21, 2020, The Uzbekistan Special Republican Commission has made changes to entry requirements for visitors arriving by air, rail and road which will come into force on 1 October 2020. The Commission is monitoring the epidemiological situation in foreign countries, and has categorised them as Red, Yellow and Green. Eligible visitors arriving in Uzbekistan from a country categorised as Green (which include China, Thailand, Malaysia, South Korea, Georgia, Hungary, Finland, Latvia, Austria, and Japan) or who have been in one of these countries 14 days prior to arrival will not be subject to any mandatory quarantine or self-isolation period unless they display symptoms on arrival. Those arriving in Uzbekistan from a country categorised as Yellow (Azerbaijan, Belarus, the UAE, and the EU (except for the UK and Spain)) 14 days prior to arrival are subject to a mandatory period of 14-days self-isolation on arrival. Travel from a country categorised as Red (UAE, Turkey, Iran, Afghanistan, Russia and other CIS countries and the USA) is only permitted for Uzbek Nationals repatriating from these countries. All arrivals from countries categorised as Red or who have been in one of these countries in the 14 days prior to arrival are subject to a mandatory 14-day quarantine period in a government facility.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_region: European Union (without the UK),Other Regions (please specify below)

description: According to the news report on March 25, 2020, in Uzbekistan, Internal Affairs Ministry won't fine for expired vehicle inspection and violation of passport system provisions during quarantine. The migration and citizenship registration departments of the internal affairs bodies, as well as the State Road Safety Service, temporarily suspend the admission of citizens, foreigners and stateless persons, and legal entities from March 24 until special recommendations are received. The implementation of activities related to administrative practice, taking exams, registration and technical inspection of vehicles is suspended. For this reason, drivers who fail to carry out state registration and technical inspection of motor vehicles, pay fines in a timely manner, will not be fined temporarily. ​

description: Uzbekistan reported its first confirmed case of COVID-19 on March 16, 2020. The authorities implemented extensive measures to prevent the spread of the virus including: restricting travel (including international flights, domestic public transportation, and movement by car), closing borders (except for trade), closing schools, universities, and all stores except grocery stores and pharmacies, and cancelling public events and religious gatherings. Government employees were asked to telework or to stay home. However, no protection for elderly people was declared.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: TASHKENT, March 22 (Reuters) - Uzbekistan ordered all companies in the capital Tashkent on Sunday to switch to remote working and made protective masks mandatory in all major cities in order to prevent the spread of coronavirus.    The government also said those not wearing masks in public in any of the major Uzbek cities would be fined $22 at first and $67 for repeat offences.    Announced on 22 March, the measure will come into effect on 23 March and fines will be applied from 25 March.    Whether the measure will be applied in other towns and villages is not mentioned.

target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: According to the order of the special republican commission of Uzbekistan on May 15, 2020, citizens will be able to use their personal car around the clock in regions with a "green" quarantine level. Without permissive stickers in the "yellow" regions, it is allowed to move from 06:00 to 22:00. In this case, there should not be more than 4 people in the cabin. In the "red" regions, citizens will be able to use their personal car from 07:00 to 10:00 and from 17:00 to 20:00 to travel to and from work, to buy medicines, medical supplies and essential goods.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

UPDATE: The policy has been annulled since, in the Republic of Uzbekistan, according to the new order of the special republican commission from May 18, 2020, citizens will be able to use their personal car around the clock in regions with a “green” quarantine level. Without permissive stickers in the "yellow" regions, it is allowed to move from 06:00 to 22:00. In this case, there should not be more than 4 people in the cabin. In the “red” regions, citizens will be able to use their personal car from 07:00 to 10:00 and from 17:00 to 20:00 to travel to and from work, to buy medicines, medical supplies and essential goods.

description: Uzbekistan: According to the decision of the Tashkent khokim, it was reported that, starting from 22 March 2020, the movement of public transport (buses, metro and fixed-route taxis) temporarily ceases — regardless of the form of ownership — which renders services of carriers on routes in the territory of Tashkent. UPDATE: Starting from 8 June 2020, public transport in the “yellow” and “green” zones will resume their operation. At the first stage, in the “yellow” and “green” quarantine zones, buses of city (district) and suburban routes will go on line. Damas cars, minibuses and the subway will not work yet. The corresponding decision was made by the Special Republican Commission.

description: By the decision of the Special Commission of the Republic of Uzbekistan, from August 20, 2020, large markets and stores, gyms, fitness centers and swimming pools will be allowed to reopen with the requirement of regular disinfection and social distancing. Staff is required to wear masks and gloves. In large markets, customers should be provided with free gloves. Customers should have a temperature check. Team sports, where maintaining social distance is not possible, are prohibited.

description: In Uzbekistan, classes for first-year students in the current academic year will begin on October 12.  Classes will be held online, however, a small number of introductory classes will be held in traditional form in order to familiarize students with the campus and teaching staff and to explain the procedure for online learning. Introductory classes will last from 3 days to 2 weeks. There will be no more than 2 classes per day.
